Debby drank two whiskey sodas before the start - and either on account
of that load of false
or in spite of it - enjoyed the exper-
lence as did all the others.
was some confusion at the Fitz-
simmons and our chairs were
all sent back down so after dinner there
nothering to do but walk down in the pitch dark.
We borrowed two
of Mr. Fitzsimmons boys with lanterns
made the descent without
any casualties.
It was exeiting for Debby
girls - me too -
walking through the several
x** villages
so late at night.
following day we went over early to Chungking
sole shopping.
It was Debby's birthday and what a place
spend it!
Chungking the dirtiest most disorderly city in the world,
a lot of opium lamps - each of the
We bought
girls bought a pipe and a lot of
gadgets.
Poppies are still one of the stable crops in Szechuen
Province and it is about as hard to find a place to smoke opium as
to buy a drink in New York during probition days.
few hours in Chungking we went baok
the river and
pionio party on a hike to
the Asiatic Petroleum sumner camp
the see ond
of mountains.
was a long hard elimb.
took a chair but
us walked.
I regretted being scornful
of that chair
many times and to
getting old.
can't take it.
discovered
Buck Mountain and wasn't
so bad for
The chun an a bout rulent to
the Chungking folks
used to shagging those heights as a matter of daily routine
us it was quite another
matter coming from Shanghai
where the highest
Garden Bridge
over Soochow
Creek which at the highest point
is 8 feet above sea level
as contrasted with the general elevation
of 6 feet for the rest
Anyway we lived through it and
the bottle of beer which I had at the camp was almost worth
to say nothing of the view.
Our party consisted of
traveling companions of Debby and the girls.
Mr. and Mrs. Bragg who
a Mr. Robinson whom Mr.
Bragg is sueceeding, a Dr.
Wood off the
Chungking and a very attractive young fellow who is the Standard 01l
No. 2 man
at Chungking.
We had a grand
time and coming down stopped off for tea
with some
old friends of mine Mr. and Mrs. Holm. Postal
Commissioner.
They have lived many years in China and Mrs. Holm with rare good taste
collected a housefull of Chinese art objeets which makes her
most attractive by far of any house I have seen in China.
The house is of Chinese architecture set amid a lovely garden over-
looking the Yangtaze and the city of Chungking which is ploturesque
and interesting when sufficiently far away to be non-offensive
senses of eye,
ear and nose.
We had tea including the best cake you
have ever eaten plus a lavish supply of divinity candy,
with the
result that the girls did fairly
well toward restoring
few pounds
which the climb had removed.
After tea with the Holm family we
went to the International Club where
most all of the 30 foreign population
of Chungking had gathered to hear a lecture by
Capt. Settle of
Navy on the
subjeat of his trip of 60,000 feet into the stratosphere.
Very interestingâ€¢
After that we had
dinner on the fantung and turned
in early as we were sailing early the next morning.
The cook boy had
baked a birthday cake for Debby which looked poisonous on the outside
all decorated with red, green and yellow icing - but the inside was
I had arranged to take the boat as far as Wanhsien and fly
from there to Hankow
as I want to be back in Shanghai Sunday.
sailed at dawn and had a perfect day - bright sunshine.
I was pretty
well tired out as a result
of several weeks of intensive work and just
relaxed in a steamer chair on the top deck.
It was grand.
We arrived
Wenhsien that night and
the following morning the boat sailed just
been made
at damed that the end el trusted
